Description: Narrow ovoid marl pottery jar with flat base, ledge rim and two pierced cylindrical handles on shoulder, decorated on the exterior in red-brown paint with representations of two many-oared boats, two ‘Naqada plants’ and bush motifs. The rim top is painted with a wavy line; horizontal wavy lines appear above and over the handles. Three wavy lines run across the base.
Curator's comments: Like Decorated ware D41A in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). One boat has a tree with four fronds at the prow and two central cabins with a Z-shaped standard appended to the right cabin. Below the boat is a bush motif. The other boat has a more amorphous frond at the prow. Appended to the right cabin is a standard that appears to represent a harpoon with a barb at one end and cordage at the other. Below this boat is also a bush motif. Below each handle is a Naqada plant and a row of S-motifs; a series of broken lines appears below the Naqada plant on one side only. Published: G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 358
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
